message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The genetic abnormality suggests Angelman syndrome, and the clinical features, such as developmental delay, cognitive disability, uncoordinated movements, and inappropriate laughter, support this diagnosis. Angelman syndrome is caused by the deletion or inactivation of genes on the maternally inherited chromosome 15. Therefore, the most likely pattern of gene expression in this patient is abnormally decreased expression of the gene from the maternal chromosome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The abnormality in an E3 ubiquitin ligase gene suggests that this patient has Angelman syndrome, which is caused by a maternal chromosomal deletion or mutation of the UBE3A gene. Therefore, the most likely pattern of gene expression is abnormally decreased expression of the gene from the maternal chromosome.

We refer to the NCBI article on E3 ubiquitin ligases for help. E3 ubiquitin ligase is necessary for protein ubiquitination and degradation, and defects in the gene can cause neurological disorders such as seizures and developmental delays. The patient’s phenotype suggests Angelman syndrome, which is caused by a deficiency in the maternal copy of the UBE3A gene found on chromosome 15q11-q13. Therefore, the most likely pattern of gene expression in this patient is abnormally decreased expression of the gene from the maternal chromosome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a previous genetic abnormality in an E3 ubiquitin ligase gene, which is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. This means that both copies of the gene need to be affected to cause disease. Thus, the most likely pattern of gene expression seen in this patient is abnormally decreased expression of the gene from the maternal chromosome, as the other copy (paternal) is already abnormal.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The abnormality in the E3 ubiquitin ligase gene suggests a genetic disorder, and the uncoordinated movements and developmental delay suggest that the patient may have Angelman syndrome, which is associated with a deletion or inactivation of the maternal copy of the UBE3A gene. Therefore, the answer is (B), abnormally decreased expression of the gene from the maternal chromosome.

We refer to medical genetics textbooks for help. Since the patient has an abnormality in an E3 ubiquitin ligase gene, which functions in the removal of proteins, it suggests that the protein levels of certain molecules may be abnormal in this patient. This type of genetic abnormality is known as an imprinting disorder and would result in differential gene expression depending on whether the gene was inherited from the mother or father. Therefore, option (B), abnormally decreased expression of the gene from the maternal chromosome, is most likely seen in this patient. This is because some genes are imprinted, meaning only one allele is expressed, and in this case, the maternal allele is silenced.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The abnormality in the E3 ubiquitin ligase gene suggests a diagnosis of Angelman syndrome, which is caused by a deletion of the maternal chromosome. Therefore, the most likely pattern of gene expression is abnormally decreased expression of the gene from the maternal chromosome.

We refer to articles on genetics for help. Since the patient has an abnormality in an E3 ubiquitin ligase gene, it is likely that this is an X-linked disorder, as this gene is located on the X chromosome. The patient is male and therefore only has one X chromosome, which he receives from his mother. Thus, abnormally decreased expression of the gene from the maternal chromosome is most likely seen in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fact that the patient has an abnormality in an E3 ubiquitin ligase gene suggests that they have Angelman syndrome, a rare genetic disorder. This condition is caused by the loss of function or deletion of the maternally inherited UBE3A gene in chromosome 15. Therefore, option (B) - abnormally decreased expression of the gene from the maternal chromosome - is the most likely pattern of gene expression in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fact that the patient has an abnormality in an E3 ubiquitin ligase gene suggests a genetic disorder known as Angelman syndrome. This syndrome is caused by the loss of function of a gene on the maternal chromosome. Therefore, option (B), indicating abnormally decreased expression of the gene from the maternal chromosome, is the most likely pattern of gene expression in this patient.
